titleStmt.title: Tamiḻneṟi Viḷakkam 24.
Experimenting with formatting for the final edition.

witness.expan: A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [ante correctionem]
A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [post correctionem]

div.p: Informing [the confidante] about the type of separation; [the hero] rightfully suffering when her companion speaks [of the heroine's state]; [the confidante] saying "I know" when there is no [more] anguish; the one with the fragrant foerhead lamenting; [the confidante] speaking so that [the heroine] becomes amenable [to the separation]; she with the clear jewels agreeing; [the hero and his heart] becoming confused together on the journey; [the heroine] suffering because the time has come; while the confidate says [the heroine] has suffered, [the hero] says she is one who [still] suffersThis is not clear. Based on the poems in the commentary, this situation includes lots of possible other situations. I have understood it this way as thins is how the commentator seems to have interpreted it, and there are no other sources of information.; and [the confidante] comforting [the heroine] - understand [these situations] are the long-distance separation, [which] also [apply to] the man who comes from 'that place'.
eṉpatu cēy iṭaip pirivām āṟuṇarttutaṉutaliṟṟu.
The quoted [cūttiram] intends to make known the way in which 'the long-distance separation' occurs.
pirivuṇarttutaṉ mutal ākap peyarntōṉ kūṟṟīṟākac collap paṭṭaṉa cēy iṭaip pirivām eṉṟa vāṟu.
Beginning with informing and ending with returning, those things that have been mentioned are 'the long-distance separation'.
eṉpatu talaimakaṉ tōḻikkup pirivuṇarttiyatu.
The hero informs the confidante about his separation.
eṉpatu tōḻi talaimakaṇilaimai kūṟic celavaḻuṅkuvittatu.
The confidante stopping [the hero] going by talking about the state of the heroine.
ituvum atu.
And this is that.
eṉpatu talaimakaṉeñciṟkuc collic celavaḻuṅkuvittatu.
The hero desists from going after speaking to his heart.
ituvum atu.
And this is that.
eṉpatu aḻuṅkātu celavu kuṟitta talaimakaṉukkut tōḻi colliyatu.
The confidante speaks to the hero who had inteded to go without regret.
eṉpatu tōḻi talaimakaṭkuk kuṟippiṉāṟ pirivuṇarttiyatu.
The confidante informs the heroine of [the hero's] separation through allusions.
eṉpatu kalvi viḷakkuvāṉ pirivar eṉa veḷip paṭa vuṇarttiyatu.
[The confidante] informs [the heroine] clearly that he will separate for the sake of further study.
eṉpatu kāttaṟkup pirivar eṉa vuṇarttiyatu.
[The confidante] informs [the heroine] that he will separate to guard [the realm].
eṉpatu pakai taṇippāṉ pirivar eṉa vuṇarttiyatu.
[The confidante] informs [the heroine] that he will separate to appease enmity.
eṉpatu vēntaṟ kuṟṟuḻip pirivar eṉa vuṇarttiyatu.
[The confidante] informs [the heroine] that he will separate for a royal emergency.
eṉpatu poruḷ vayiṟ pirivar eṉa vuṇarttiyatu.
[The confidante] informs [the heroine] that he will separate for the sake of wealth.
eṉpatu pirivar eṉpatu kēṭṭa talaimakaḷ āṟṟāḷ āyt tōḻikkuc colliyatu.
The heroine, who had heard that he will separate, cannot bear it and speaks to the confidante.
eṉpatu āṟṟāḷ āya talaimakaṭkut tōḻi pirivu nayappac colliyatu.
The confidante speaks to the heroine, who had become unable to bear [the sitaution], to make her agree to the separation.
ituvum atu.
And this is that.
eṉpatu talaimakaḷ pirivuṭaṉ paṭṭatu.
The heroine agrees to [the hero's] separation.
eṉpatu pirivuṭaṉ paṭṭa talaimakaṭalaimakaṟkuc colliyatu.
The heroine, who had agreed to [his] separation, speaks to the hero.
eṉpatu pirintu cellun talaimakaṉ ṟērp pākaṟkuc colliyatu.
The hero, who had separated [from the heroine] and left, speaks to the charioteer.
eṉpatu talaimakaṉ iṭaic curattut talaimakaḷai niṉaintu neñciṉait teḷittuc ceṉṟatu.
The hero, after clarifying [the matter] with his heart, which was thinking of the heroine in the middle of the desert, goes on.
eṉpatu talaimakaṉ aṟiyāmaṟ pirinta viṭattut talaimakaḷ āṟṟātu colliyatu.
Without knowledge of the hero during the separation, the heroine speaks, unable to bear it.
eṉpatu paruvavaravu kaṇṭāṟṟāḷ āyatu.
On seeing the season [of his arrival] coming, [the heroine] becomes disconsolate.
ituvum atu.
And this is that.
eṉpatu talaimakaḷ āṟṟāmaikkut tōḻi yāṟṟāḷ āyiṟṟu.
The confidante, because the heroine cannot bear [the separation], becomes disconsolate.
eṉpatu āṟṟāḷ āya tōḻikkāṟṟuval eṉpatu paṭac colliyatu.
[The heroine] speaks to the confidante, who had become disconsolate, to be told something comforting.
eṉpatu tōḻi yāṟṟuvippāṉ ṟalaimakaṉai iyaṟ paḻittatu.
The confidante belittles the nature of the hero to comfort [the heroine].
eṉpatu talaimakaḷ ataṉukkāṟṟāḷ āy moḻintatu.
The heroine, having become disconsolate on account of that [separation], speaks.
eṉpatu paruvam aṉṟeṉa vāṟṟuvittatu.
[The confidante] comforts [the heroine] by saying, "It is not the season [of his return]."
eṉpatu tēr varavu kūṟi yāṟṟuvittatu.
[The confidante] comforting [the heroine] by talking about [the hero's] chariot coming.
eṉpatu viṉai muṭittu mīḷvāṉeñciṟkuc colliyatu.
Having completed his task, the one who was returning speaks to his heart.
eṉpatu mukilukkuc colliyatu.
[The hero] speaks to a cloud.
eṉpatu tērp pākaṟkuc colliyatu.
[The hero] speaks to the charioteer.
eṉpatu tōḻi caṅkiṉai vāḻttiyatu.
The confidante praises the conch.
eṉpatu talaimakaṭkut tōḻi colliyatu.
The confidante speaks to the heroine.
eṉpatu talaimakaṭkut talaimakaṉ colliyatu. 24.
The hero speaks to the heroine.

standOff.note: Cf. TP27i: ōtal pakaiyē tūtivai pirivē
Cf. IA35: pukaḻum koṭumaiyum kiḻavōṉ mēṉa
Cf. IAC39, p.169: iṉi, poruṭkup piriyāluṟṟa talaimakaḷ tōḻiyāl talaimakaṭkup pirivu uṇarttivittaṟkuc ceyyul:
Cf. IAC39, p.169: tōḻi talaimakaḷ nilaimai talaimakaṟkuc colliyataṟku ceyyuḷ:

Cf. IAC35, p.159: ōtaṟku piriyum eṉpatu, kaṟpāṉ piriyum eṉpataṉṟu; paṇṭē kuravarkaḷāṟ kaṟpikkappaṭṭuk kaṟṟāṉ, aṟam poruḷ iṉpam vīṭupeṟukaḷ nutaliya nūlkaḷellām; iṉip, paratēcaṅkaḷiṉum avai vellār uḷareṉiṟ kāṇṭaṟkum, vallārkaḷ uḷvaḻic ceṉṟu taṉ ñāṉam mēṟpaṭuttu avar ñāṉaṅ kīḻppaṭuttaṟkum piriyum eṉakkoḷka.
Cf. IAC39, p.64: vēntaṟkuṟṟuḻip pirivyun talaimakaṉ tōḻiyāl talaimakaṭkup pirivuṇarttuvittu piriyum;
Cf. IAC39, p.169: poruṭkup piriyaluṟṟa talaimakaḷ tōḻiyāl talaimakaṭkup pirivu uṇarttuvittaṟkuc ceyyul:
Cf. IAC39, p.169: atu kēṭṭu āṟṟāttaṉmaiyaḷāya talaimakaḷ tōḻikkuc colliyataṟkuc ceyyuḷ:
Cf. IAC39, p.166: vēntarkkuṟṟuḻic ceṉṟu viṉaimuṟṟi miḷvāṉ tērp pākaṟkuc colliyataṟkuc ceyyuḷ:

Cf. IAC53, p.194: ivai piriviṭaip paruvaṅkaṇṭu āṟṟāḷāya talaimakaḷai 'itu paruvamaṉṟu; eṉṉai, avar poyyuraiyārākalāṉ; ituvum vampu; vampiṉaip paruvam eṉṟu tam maṭamaiyāṟ piṭavum kōṭalum koṉṟaiyum mayaṅkip pūttaṉa' eṉṟu vaṟpuṟuttāḷ

In the IAC, it is the confidante who says this to console the heroine, whereas here it is the heroine's lament. Even though the speech is just a summary of what is found in NA99, which is quoted as a source of the poem, it is still included as it is impossible to know whether the commentator drew from the NA poem or the prose summary.
Cf. IAC53, p.193: talaimakaṉṟaṉṉai, 'aṉpilaṉ koṭiyaṉ' eṉavum ittoṭakkattaṉa ellāñ colliyum āṟṟuvikkum.
Cf. IAC39, p.170: piriviṭai melinta āṟṟāḷākiya talaimakaḷaip paruvam vanteṉṟu vaṟpuṟuppa, vaṉpoṟai yotiraḻinta colliyataṟkuc ceyyuḷ:
Cf. IAC53, p.193: avaṟṟuṭ paruva varaviṉkaṇ āṟṟāḷāya talaimakaḷai āṟṟuvittaṟkup paṭaittu moḻintu paruvamaṉṟu eṉṟataṟkuc ceyyuḷ:
Cf. IAC53, p.194: piriviṭaiyāṟṟḷākiya talaimakaḷait tōḻi, 'avar kuṟitta paruvam vantākaliṉ avarum poyyār, varuvar' eṉṟu vaṟpuṟuttiyatu.
Cf. IAC55, p.198: caṅka paṭakam icaippac caṅkiṉai vāḻttic colliyataṟkuc ceyyuḷ:
Cf. PK240.1-2 (IAC36, p.162): tēkkiya teṇtirai munnīr irunilam tītakalak | kākkiya celvatu kātalit tāraṉpar...
Cf. PK241.1-2 (IAC37, p.163): tākkiya pōrvaya vēnta riruvarkkuñ cantiṭainiṉ | ṟākkiya celvatu kātalit tārnamar...
Cf. PK242.1-2 (IAC39, p.164): vārār muraciṉ viraicēr malarmuṭi maṉṉavaṟkāyc | cērār muṉaimicaic cēṟaluṟ ṟarnamar...
Cf. PK243.1-2 (IAC39, p.164): kaṉṉavil tōḷmaṉṉaṉ temmuṉai mēṟkala vāraivelvāṉ | viṉṉavil tōḷaṉpar celvar...
Cf. PK251.1-2 (IAC39, p.164): veṉṟē kaḷitta cevvēlneṭu māṟaṉviṉ ṭārmuṉaimēl | ceṉṟē viṉaimuṟṟi mīṇṭaṉam...
Cf. KT11.3-4:...āṅkē | yeḻuviṉi vāḻiyeṉ ṉeñcē...
Cf. AN19.1-2: aṉṟava ṉōḻinraṉṟu mailaiyē vantunaṉi | varuntiṉai vāḻiye ṉeñcē...
Cf. KT43:celvā rallareṉ ṟiyāṉikaḻn taṉaṉē | yīvā ḷallaḷeṉ ṟavarikaḻn taṉarē | yāyiṭai yirupē rāṇmai ceyta pūca | ṉallarāk katuvi yāṅke | ṉalla ṉeñca malamalak kuṟumē ||

Cf. PK300 (IAC52, p.192): cellār avareṉ ṟiyāṉikaḻn tēṉcurañ cellattaṉkaṇ | ollāḷ avaḷeṉ ṟavarikaḻn tārmaṟ ṟuvayiraṇṭum | kollār ayiṟpaṭaik kōṉneṭu māṟaṉ kuḷantaiveṉṟa | villāṉ pakaipōl eṉatuḷḷan taṉṉai melivikkumē ||
Cf. NA99.8-10:...tērvila | piṭavuṅ koṉṟaiyuṅ kōṭalu | maṭava vākaliṉ malarntaṉa palavē ||
Cf. PK305.3-4 (IAC53, p.194):... varuntal pirinta tuḷaṅkoḷiyār | aṭiyār kaḻalār aṇukavan tārtta takalvicumpē ||
Cf. PK307.3-4 (IAC53, p.195): varuntal maṭantai varuvarnam kātalar vāṉatirak | kuruntam poruntiveṇ mullaikaḷ īṉṟaṉa kūreyiṟē ||

I assume UVC was influenced by the phrase illamoṭu miṭainta in NA376 though he does not provide a footnote so it is difficult to know for sure. illoṭu sill makes sense, so I have retained the MS reading.
Cf. PK251.2-4:...kārum ciṟitiruṇṭa | tiṉṟē pukumvaṇṇam ūrkatiṇ tēriḷa vañciyeṉṉa | niṉṟē vaṇaṅku nuṭaṅkiṭai ēḻai neṭunakarkkē ||
Cf. PK256.2-4:... muṉṉutēr | neymmāṇ ayilneṭu māṟaṉ niṟaipuṉal kūṭalaṉṉa | maimmāṇ kuḻalāḷ maramaṉṟu vāṇiṭai vārpuyalē ||
Cf. PK314.2-4 (IAC55, p.198):... mālkaṭal tōṉṟiṉai maṇṇaḷanta | nīṉiṟa vaṇṇaṉum ēntiṉan tammuṉ niṟampuraitīm | pāṉiṟa veṇcaṅkam yārniṉṉiṉ mikka paṭimaiyarē ||
Cf. IAC55, p.198: purivaḷai vāṉkōṭu puttēḷō ṭotti | tiruvamar mārpaṉu mēntiṉaṉ tammuṉ | uruvam puraiyumniṉ kēḻ ||

In lieu of an apparatus, I simply provide the full transcription of the poem as found in the palm-leaf MS. The text in the paper copy of the MS and print editions are identical. It is not clear how UVC arrived at this text. Perhaps the palm-leaf has deteriorated in the years since he acquired it.

Cf. PK303 (IAC53, p.194): pūritta meṉmulai yāyaṉṟu pūlantaip pōrmalainta | vērit toṭaiyal vicaya caritaṉviṇ tōykollimēl | mūrik kaḷiṟu muṉintukai eṟṟa muḻaṅkukoṇṭal | mārikku mullaiyiṉ vāynaka vēnī varuntuvatē ||
